title: What Makes a Superpower: New Perspectives on China‚Äôs Rise
description:
Saori N. Katada is Associate Professor at School of International Relations at University of Southern California. She is a co-author of a book The BRICS and Collective Financial Statecraft (Oxford University Press, 2017), and a forthcoming book Unconventional Politics: Ideas, Policy Networks and Japan‚Äôs Monetary Policymaking under Deflation (tentative title, Cornell University Press). Her single-authored book Banking on Stability: Japan and the Cross-Pacific Dynamics of International Financial Crisis Management (University of Michigan Press, 2001) received Masayoshi Ohira Memorial Book Award.  She has also published six edited and co-edited books and numerous articles on the subjects of trade, financial and monetary cooperation in East Asia as well as Japanese foreign aid.  She is currently working on a book manuscript on Japan‚Äôs foreign economic policy and East Asian regionalism.  For her research on regionalism, she was recently awarded Asia Studies Fellow at the East-West Center in Washington, Japan Foundation Research Grant and National Endowment for the Humanities Fellowship.  She has her Ph.D. from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (Political Science) in 1994, and B.A. from Hitotsubashi University (Tokyo). 

Our video series ‚ÄúWhat Makes a Superpower: New Perspectives on China‚Äôs Rise‚Äù was filmed on the sidelines of our 2018 lecture series held at the University of G√∂ttingen from April to June. In our conversations with Liu Kang, Todd Hall and Saori Katade we discuss China‚Äôs rise from the angle of political thought and Chinese exceptionalism, debate emotions in international relations and examine China‚Äôs diplomacy as well as its role within the BRICS countries.

In this video Saori Katada discusses three questions:
1. Can you tell us about your recent publication The BRICS and Collective Financial Statecraft?  How can we evaluate BRICS role within an ongoing global power shift? 
2. What is China's role within the BRICS project?
3. In your research you tackle the question of East Asian Regionalism. What are recent dynamics and events within this process of regional integration?

More information https://www.cemeas.de/

title: Voices of Struggle: LGBTQ and Feminist Activism in China and Beyond
description:
Fan Popo (ËåÉÂù°Âù°) is an activist and filmmaker currently based in Berlin. He has made many documentaries on LGBT/gender issues in China including New Beijing New Marriage, Be a Woman, Chinese Closet, Mama Rainbow, The VaChina Monologues, Papa Rainbow. 

Of late he has moved into fictional/experimental films. He has been a committee member of Beijing Queer Film Festival since 2007, and he also organized the China Queer Film Festival Tour.  In 2015, he sued the government for banning his film Mama Rainbow after more than one million hits online. It was a landmark event for freedom of speech in China and was covered by many domestic and international news outlets.

Our video series ‚ÄúVoices of Struggle: LGBTQ and Feminist Activism in China and Beyond‚Äù was filmed on the sidelines of a symposium of the same name held at the University of G√∂ttingen on 17 April 2018. In our conversations with four of the participants (Hongwei Bao, Maizi Li, Popo Fan, Harriet Evans) we explore the complex entanglements between activism and academia in transnational perspective. What does it mean to be an engaged or activist scholar today? How should we think about the connections/separations between the two spheres of activism and academia? And how can activists and academics best combine their strengths to effect change? In what ways are deepening transnational connections re-shaping the practice of activism around the globe? Our two day event brought together leading scholars and activists to discuss these questions in relation to the development of feminism and LGBTQ activism in China and beyond.

More information https://www.cemeas.de/

title: What Makes a Superpower: New Perspectives on China‚Äôs Rise
description:
Prof. Kang Liu (Duke University) is Professor of Chinese Studies, and Director of Duke Program of Research on China at Duke University. Professor Liu is Elected Member of Academia Europaea (The Academy of Europe) since 2015. He is the author of twelve books, and written widely in scholarly journals in both English and Chinese. In addition, He frequently contributes in the forms of op-eds, interviews, reviews, to American and Chinese print media and the internet media, on issues ranging from contemporary Chinese media and culture, globalization, to Marxism and aesthetics.

Our video series ‚ÄúWhat Makes a Superpower: New Perspectives on China‚Äôs Rise‚Äù was filmed on the sidelines of our 2018 lecture series held at the University of G√∂ttingen from April to June. In our conversations with Liu Kang, Todd Hall and Saori Katade we discuss China‚Äôs rise from the angle of political thought and Chinese exceptionalism, debate emotions in international relations and examine China‚Äôs diplomacy as well as its role within the BRICS countries.

In this video Kang LIU discusses four questions:
1. What is the rise of China?
2. What is Chinese exceptionalism, and how does it differ from American exceptionalism?
3. How does the world see China's rise and how are global attitudes towards China changing?
4. How does the concept of soft power relate to China‚Äôs emergence as a global player?

More information https://www.cemeas.de/

title: Voices of Struggle: LGBTQ and Feminist Activism in China and Beyond
description:
Hongwei Bao is an Assistant Professor in Media Studies at the University of Nottingham in England. He has held previous faculty positions at universities around the world including the University of Potsdam, the University of Sydney and the National Academy of Theatrical Arts in Beijing. 

As a scholar, Bao‚Äôs pathbreaking research aims to bring queer theory, Marxism and China into dialogue with each other. By looking at queer media production, queer filmmaking, and LGBT social organisations in contemporary China, he theorises how sexual identities emerge in a neoliberal and postsocialist context and how a radical queer public culture can be made.
His new book, titled Queer Comrades: Gay Identity and Queer Politics in Postsocialist China, was published by NIAS Press in 2018. The book offers in-depth analysis of recent queer history and contemporary cultural texts, including the processes by which queer theory and activism was introduced and received in the PRC. Another of our panelists, the queer filmmaker Fan Popo features centrally in Bao‚Äôs book. Fan is also a central subject in the talk that Bao will give to us today, ‚ÄúPerforming Queer in the Theatre-Documentary Convergence.‚Äù

Our video series ‚ÄúVoices of Struggle: LGBTQ and Feminist Activism in China and Beyond‚Äù was filmed on the sidelines of a symposium of the same name held at the University of G√∂ttingen on 17 April 2018. In our conversations with four of the participants (Hongwei Bao, Maizi Li, Popo Fan, Harriet Evans) we explore the complex entanglements between activism and academia in transnational perspective. What does it mean to be an engaged or activist scholar today? How should we think about the connections/separations between the two spheres of activism and academia? And how can activists and academics best combine their strengths to effect change? In what ways are deepening transnational connections re-shaping the practice of activism around the globe? Our two day event brought together leading scholars and activists to discuss these questions in relation to the development of feminism and LGBTQ activism in China and beyond.

title: India and the Tokyo Trial (1946‚Äì48)
description:
Is the demand for codified international criminal justice antithetical to the demand for agonistic decolonization of global political, military, and economic power? Or can the establishment of global norms of justice be made compatible with, and even grounded upon, anti-colonial and democratic interventions? By analysing Indian involvement in the Tokyo Trial (1946‚Äì48), this paper foregrounds some of the key complexities at stake in the dialectics between global norm-building and anti-colonial agonism. While existing scholarship has mainly dwelt upon legal and political history, I draw upon methodological debates in the nascent field of global intellectual history to sharply focus on the tense relation between sovereignty and natural law which mediated discussions on justice in relation to colonialism, in the Tokyo moment as well as in its long aftermath. I give particular attention to the dissenting Indian judge at the trial, Radhabinod Pal (1886‚Äì1967), and contextualize his controversial judgment in relation to (anti-) colonial politics and justice, not merely in relation to the Japanese Empire ‚Äì and the decades-old Indian engagement with Japanese models of sovereignty ‚Äì but also in relation to British India, Dutch Indonesia, French Indochina, and Korea. 

Milinda Banerjee is LMU Research Fellow from February 2017 to January 2019, as well as Assistant Professor in the Department of History at Presidency University (Kolkata, India). He defended his PhD in Heidelberg University (November 2014). His dissertation, which offered an intellectual history of concepts and practices of rulership and sovereignty in colonial India (with a primary focus on Bengal, ca. 1858-1947), is now forthcoming as a book. His research project at LMU is titled ‚ÄòSovereignty versus Natural Law? The Tokyo Trial in Global Intellectual History‚Äô. Banerjee specializes in the intersections of South Asian and global intellectual history, and is the author of several journal articles and book chapters, and the co-editor of the volume, Transnational Histories of the 'Royal Nation' (Palgrave, 2017).

description:
Tacit, accumulated knowledge is essential for the intonaition of an organ. In this film, organ builder Rainer Janke demonstrates how to make copies of baroque and romantic flue pipes that maintain the sound of the respective era. Individual steps in this craft process can be fully appreciated; just as relevant is the accumulated experiential know-how in achieving historical sound. The film is the result of a project conducted with funds from the German Federal Ministry of Science and Research.

title: CeMEAS Conversations Ge Zhaoguang: How did China become a modern nation-state?
description:
Ge Zhaoguang is a Distinguished Professor of Fudan University, Shanghai, China. He received his BA and MA from Peking University (1982, 1984).  Before he joined Fudan in 2007, he was professor in the History Department of Tsinghua University in Beijing from 1992 to 2006. Prof. Ge served as Director of National Institute for Advanced Humanistic Studies at Fudan University from 2007 to 2013.

Prof. Ge‚Äôs research focuses on ancient China, its religion, culture and history. His works include: A History of Chinese Zen Buddhist Thought: From the 6th to 10th Century (1995, 2006); An Intellectual History of China (Volume 1-2, 1998, 2000); Here in ‚ÄòChina‚Äô I Dwell: Reconstructing Historical Discourses of China for Our Time (2011, its English translation was recently published by Brill in 2017); Inner and Outer in Historical China (2017), etc. Prof. Ge has won a series of book prizes, including Asia Pacific awards in Japan (2014), Paju Book Award in South Korea (2014), HongKong Book Award (2015).

title: CeMEAS Conversations:  ‚ÄûSocial Policy in China ‚Äì Retrospect and Prospect"
description:
Mark W. Frazier is Professor of Politics at The New School, where he also serves as Academic Director of the India China Institute. He teaches and writes about social policy in China and efforts to reduce inequalities. His recent research draws comparisons between China and India in terms of how each has coped with challenges related to inequality and urbanization. In his capacity as a director at the India China Institute, he works with faculty colleagues to sponsor research projects and conferences to support scholarship on comparative research on China and India, as well as Sino-Indian relations and their joint impact on the rest of the world. He is the author of Socialist Insecurity: Pensions and the Politics of Uneven Development in China (Cornell University Press, 2010) and The Making of the Chinese Industrial Workplace (Cambridge University Press, 2002). He has authored op-ed pieces and essays for The New York Times, Daedalus, and The Diplomat. Frazier has taken part in the National Committee on US-China Relations (NCUSCR) Public Intellectual Program since 2005. Before assuming his current position at The New School in 2012, he held faculty positions at the University of Oklahoma and at Lawrence University.
https://www.newschool.edu/nssr/faculty/Mark%20W.-Frazier/

title: CeMEAS Conversations Victor Shih: What is the Future of Made in China?
description:
Our video series ‚ÄúWhat is the Future of Made in China?‚Äù was filmed on the sidelines of a symposium of the same name  held at the University of G√∂ttingen on 17 July 2017 which drew together many of the leading thinkers on this topic from around the globe. In our conversations with three of these experts (Barry Naughton, Victor Shih, and Doris Fischer) we explore China‚Äôs new  generation of muscular industrial policies that aim at making China a high-tech economy and innovation superpower. The conversations offer insight into what lies ahead for the Chinese economy and illuminate the implications of China‚Äôs plans for European countries
 with their own ambitions in an Industry 4.0 world.

Victor Shih is Associate Professor of Political Economy at the School of Global Policy & Strategy at the University of California San Diego. He has published widely on the politics of Chinese banking policies, fiscal policies and exchange rates. He was the first analyst to identify the risk of massive local government debt. He is the author of Factions and Finance in China: Elite Conflict and Inflation. Shih is currently engaged in a study of how the coalition-formation strategies of founding leaders had a profound impact on the evolution of the Chinese Communist Party.

More information https://www.cemeas.de/

 with their own ambitions in an Industry 4.0 world.

Barry Naughton
Professor Barry Naughton is the Sokwanlok Chair of Chinese International Affairs at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at the University of California San Diego. He is one of the world‚Äôs most highly respected economists working on the Chinese economy. Among dozens of influential books and articles, he wrote the authoritative textbook on the subject, The Chinese Economy: Transitions and Growth, which has now been translated into Chinese. His groundbreaking book Growing Out of the Plan: Chinese Economic Reform, 1978-1993 received the Ohira Memorial Prize.

More information https://www.cemeas.de/

Professor Doris Fischer is Chair for Chinese and Commerce at W√ºrzburg University. She has done extensive research on competition, regulation and industrial policies in various sectors in China. title: Wie k√∂nnen wir die Medizin individualisieren ?
description:
Dieser Frage gingen Wissenschaftlerinnen und Wissenschaftler im Dezember 2014 auf einem von der Deutschen Forschungsgemeinschaft gef√∂rderten Workshop an der Universit√§tsmedizin G√∂ttingen nach. Der Workshop bildete den Abschluss eines von der Deutschen Forschungsgemeinschaft gef√∂rderten Teilprojektes der Klinischen Forschergruppe ‚ÄûBiological Basis of Individual Tumor Response in Patients with Rectal Cancer". Die Forschenden untersuchten in dem Teilprojekt die ethischen Aspekte der personalisierten Rektumkarzinom-Therapie. Sie fragten, welche Erwartungen und Einstellungen Patienten gegen√ºber prognostischen Tests mit Biomarkern haben. Nach wie vor bestehen eine Reihe von ethischen Problemen in der onkologischen individualisierten Medizin. Die Wissenschaftlerinnen und Wissenschaftler wollen nun den Blick in die Zukunft richten und sich neuen Konzepten, Methoden und Strukturen widmen. Diese sollen einer individualisierten Medizin vor allem im Bereich des Wissens und Verstehens gerecht werden. Die Kommunikation hochkomplexer Daten und patientenzentrierte Gesichtspunkte der Individualisierten Medizin sollen dabei im Mittelpunkt stehen. 

Der Workshop wurde von Prof. Silke Schicktanz und Dr. Sabine W√∂hlke organsiert. Sie sehen eine Zusammenfassung der wesentlichen inhaltlichen Aspekte.
Weitere Informationen unter http://www.egm.med.uni-goettingen.de

title: Warum das Nein zur Organspende so schwer f√§llt
description:
Organtransplantationen sind in Deutschland Teil des Selbstverst√§ndnisses moderner Medizin. Zugleich werden ihre sozialen und ethischen Aspekte nicht zuletzt aufgrund j√ºngster Entwicklungen kontrovers diskutiert. Da das altruistische Spenden von Organen insbesondere im √∂ffentlichen Diskurs als w√ºnschenswert gilt, werden Zur√ºckhaltung und Skepsis allerdings vorwiegend im Kontext von Ma√ünahmen zur Steigerung der Spendenbereitschaft thematisiert. Welche Motive und √úberzeugungen tats√§chlich hinter solchen Haltungen gegen√ºber der Organspende stehen, ist in Deutschland noch weitestgehend unerforscht.
Das DFG-Projekt "'Ich m√∂chte lieber nicht.' Das Unbehagen mit der Organspende und die Praxis der Kritik. Eine soziologische und ethische Analyse (2014-2016)" setzt an dieser Stelle an und analysiert zum einen die Kritik an der Organspende und zum anderen die moralischen Botschaften √∂ffentlicher Kampagnen von Gesundheitsorganisationen. 
Das Projekt wurde durchgef√ºhrt am Institut f√ºr Soziologie, Universit√§t Erlangen-N√ºrnberg (Projektleitung: Prof. Frank Adloff) und am Institut f√ºr Ethik und Geschichte der Medizin, Universit√§tsmedizin G√∂ttingen (Projektleitung: Prof. Silke Schicktanz).
Der Film von Dr. Solveig Lena Hansen und Dr. Larissa Pfaller
entstand im Rahmen der Tagung: ‚ÄûJa? Nein? Vielleicht? Diskurs und Kritik der Organspende‚Äú, durchgef√ºhrt am 18./19. Juli 2016 am Institut f√ºr Soziologie, Universit√§t Erlangen-N√ºrnberg. Die Tagung brachte unterschiedliche Perspektiven auf die kulturellen Grundlagen der Zur√ºckhaltung, Skepsis und Kritik an der Organspende ins Gespr√§ch. Zudem wurden die aktuelle Praxis der Organspende in Deutschland, Zielkonflikte in der Aufkl√§rungsarbeit und nicht zuletzt kulturelle Vorstellungen von Spende und K√∂rperlichkeit thematisiert. Der Film zeigt die Projektergebnisse des DFG-Projektes. Sie werden durch die verantwortlichen Mitarbeiterinnen, Dr. Solveig Hansen (G√∂ttingen) und Dr. Larissa Pfaller (Erlangen) vorgestellt. 

Weitere Informationen unter http://www.egm.med.uni-goettingen.de und http://www.soziologie.phil.uni-erlangen.de/research/unbehagen-mit-organspende

title: Lebendorganspende und ihre Bedeutung f√ºr die Familie
description:
Organtransplantationen, insbesondere die Lebendspende, haben sich in den letzten 60 Jahren rasant entwickelt. Die Lebendspende spielt in der Transplantationsmedizin eine immer wichtigere Rolle. Die √∂ffentliche Debatte um die Organspende, speziell die Lebendorganspende, wird in der Hauptsache von verschiedenen Experten wie Medizinern, Juristen, Politikern oder auch dem deutschen Ethikrat gef√ºhrt. Aus ethischer Sicht ist hierbei die Frage relevant, ob damit bereits alle Perspektiven ber√ºcksichtigt sind. Wie sehen eigentlich Patienten und ihre Familien, also die Spender, die Lebendspende?

In der √∂ffentlichen Darstellung der Lebendorganspende ist auff√§llig, dass sie ausschlie√ülich als positiven Handlungsakt zwischen Liebe und F√ºrsorgepflicht dargestellt wird. Hinter der Idee der Organspende verbergen sich Vorstellungen von Solidarit√§t. Im Gegensatz zum Beispiel zur Liebe geht Solidarit√§t auf Intuition zur√ºck. Bei der postmortalen Organspende wird an eine Solidarit√§t appelliert, die sich an die Gemeinschaft, also die Gesellschaft, richtet. Bei der Lebendspende hingegen bezieht sich Solidarit√§t auf die enge Familie. 

Der Filmbeitrag verdeutlicht den Austausch einer lebend gespendeten Niere in der Familie als k√∂rperliche und kulturelle Praxis: Inwieweit kann in einer Familie √ºberhaupt eine selbstbestimmte Entscheidung f√ºr oder gegen eine Lebendorganspende getroffen werden, wenn es dabei um ein erkranktes Familienmitglied geht? 

Weitere Informationen gibt es unter http://www.egm.med.uni-goettingen.de.

title: Stakeholder-Beteiligung in der Stammzellforschung
description:
Mit humanen (menschlichen) induzierten pluripotenten Stammzellen (kurz: hiPS-Zellen) verbindet die moderne Medizin neue Hoffnungen. Es handelt sich um normale Zellen des menschlichen K√∂rpers, zum Beispiel Haut- oder Blutzellen, die im Labor so ‚Äûreprogrammiert‚Äú werden, dass daraus pluripotente Stammzellen entstehen. Pluripotente Stammzellen besitzen das Potenzial, sich zu jedem Zelltyp des menschlichen K√∂rpers zu entwickeln.
Die neue Technologie hat die Stammzellforschung revolutioniert. Bereits heute stellen hiPS-Zellen ein wichtiges Werkzeug f√ºr die Entwicklung von Krankheitsmodellen im Labor und f√ºr die Testung von Arzneimitteln dar. In Zukunft sollen hiPS-Zellen sogar f√ºr die klinische Anwendung nutzbar gemacht werden. So lie√üe sich mit hiPS-Zellen vielleicht eines Tages eine zerst√∂rte Netzhaut im Auge oder ein besch√§digter Herzmuskel reparieren. In Deutschland wurden hiPS-Zellen bislang noch nicht am Menschen angewandt. Doch der rasche Fortschritt in der medizinischen Forschung k√∂nnte dies bereits in naher Zukunft √§ndern.
Allerdings sind diese Transplantate nicht ohne Probleme. Um zu wissen, ob sie am Menschen anwendbar sind, m√ºssen klinische Versuche durchgef√ºhrt werden, die mit Risiken verbunden sind.

Am 20. und 21. Oktober 2017 fand deshalb eine Stakeholder-Konferenz zur Evaluation dieser innovativen Risikoforschung statt, veranstaltet vom Institut f√ºr Ethik und Geschichte der Medizin an der Universit√§tsmedizin G√∂ttingen. Ziel der Konferenz war es, eine Diskussion mit allen Betroffenen zu f√ºhren, um eine gerechte und ausgewogene Risikobewertung sowie Transparenz von Entscheidungsprozessen und eine informierte √∂ffentliche Debatte gew√§hrleisten zu k√∂nnen.
Weitere Informationen unter http://www.egm.med.uni-goettingen.de und http://www.clinhips.de

title: Physik im Advent - PiA 2017 (Teil 1)
description:
Ihr nennt es Spielen, wir nennen es Experimentieren 

Mit "PiA - Physik im Advent" haben wir, die Uni G√∂ttingen und die Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft (DPG), einen Adventskalender der besonderen Art entwickelt: einen physikalischen Adventskalender. Darin stellen wir Jungforscherinnen, Jungforschern und allen, die daran Spa√ü haben, 24 kleine einfache Experimente und physikalische R√§tsel vor. Sie sollen die Freude am Selber-Experimentieren wecken oder f√ºr Spannung beim Zuschauen sorgen. 

Vom 1. bis zum 24. Dezember 2017 wird jeden Tag per Video-Clip ein Experiment vorgestellt, das Ihr nachmachen k√∂nnt. Auf der Webseite k√∂nnt Ihr anschlie√üend die Fragen im Laufe des Tages beantworten. Die Aufl√∂sung der in dem Experiment aufgeworfenen physikalischen Frage erfolgt am n√§chsten Tag ebenfalls per Video. Am Ende gibt es Preise f√ºr die besten Antworten von Einzelpersonen, Schulklassen oder ganze Schulen. Macht mit! 

Weitere Informationen unter: 
http://www.physik-im-advent.de http://www.facebook.com/PhysikImAdvent

title: Physics in Advent - PiA 2017 (part 2)
description:
Physics in Advent - PiA: You call it playing, we call it experimenting.

With "PiA - Physics in Advent" we, the Georg-August-Universit√§t G√∂ttingen and the German Physical Society (DPG), developed a special kind of advent calendar. We present 24 simple experiments for young scientists and everyone who likes it. The goal is to stimulate the fun of doing experiments yourself and to enjoy watching the phenomena.

From 1. to 24. December 2017, we present a youtube movie with the experiment of the day in order for you to repeat it and to observe what happens. On our webpage, you can then answer the corresponding question via multiple-choice. We show our solution again via a youtube movie the next day.

We mainly aim at high school students at 5th to 10th grade, classes and whole schools in Germany, Austria, Switzerland or any other country. Younger and older students as well as parents and teachers and everyone else who enjoys little experiments is also welcome. This year, we offer this calendar in English and German. In the future, we might also offer the calendar in other languages. Enjoy!

Further information at 
http://www.physik-im-advent.de 
----------------------------------------¬≠----------------------------------------¬≠------ Physik im Advent - PiA: Ihr nennt es Spielen, wir nennen es Experimentieren.

Mit "PiA - Physik im Advent" haben wir, die Georg-August-Universit√§t G√∂ttingen und die Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft (DPG), einen Adventskalender der besonderen Art entwickelt: einen physikalischen Adventskalender. Darin stellen wir Jungforscherinnen, Jungforschern und allen, die daran Spa√ü haben, 24 kleine einfache Experimente und physikalische R√§tsel vor. Sie sollen die Freude am Selber-Experimentieren wecken oder f√ºr Spannung beim Zuschauen sorgen.

Vom 1. bis zum 24. Dezember 2017 wird jeden Tag per Video-Clip ein Experiment vorgestellt, das Ihr nachmachen k√∂nnt. Auf der Webseite k√∂nnt Ihr anschlie√üend die Fragen im Laufe des Tages beantworten. Die Aufl√∂sung der in dem Experiment aufgeworfenen physikalischen Frage erfolgt am n√§chsten Tag ebenfalls per Video. 

Teilnehmen k√∂nnen Sch√ºlerinnen und Sch√ºler der Klassen 5 bis 10, komplette Klassenverb√§nde oder auch ganze Schulen. J√ºngere oder √§ltere Sch√ºlerinnen und Sch√ºler, Eltern, Studierende oder Lehrkr√§fte sind aber auch herzlich eingeladen. Eingeladen sind insbesondere TeilnehmerInnen aus Deutschland, √ñsterreich, der Schweiz oder jedem anderen Land. Macht mit! 

Weitere Informationen unter 
http://www.physik-im-advent.de

title: Integrating Biodiversity Services in Agriculture
description:
Lecture by Prof. Dr. Teja Tscharntke, University of G√∂ttingen.
Abstract: Under the current scenario of rapid human population increase, combining efficient and productive agricultural land use with conserving biodiversity is a global challenge. A major argument for wildlife friendly farming and agroecological intensification is that crucial ecosystem services are provided by the ‚Äò‚Äòplanned‚Äô‚Äô and ‚Äò‚Äòassociated‚Äô‚Äô biodiversity. Loss of biological control can result in dramatic increases of pest densities, pollinator services affect a third of global human food supply, and inappropriate agricultural management can lead to environmental degradation. Hence, the true value of functional biodiversity on the farm is often inadequately acknowledged or understood, while conventional intensification tends to disrupt beneficial functions of biodiversity. Even during the last decades, high percentages of populations and species have gone extinct in human-dominated landscapes. 
This presentation is subdivided in three parts: Local management of biodiversity services, landscape design, combining land sharing with land sparing, and at a global scale, adapted solutions for smallholders. Negative externalities of pesticide use, nitrogen losses as well as disappearing pollination, biocontrol and cultural services are discussed. Landscape structure is a key factor of local ecosystem processes, so we need to better understand how to design the configurational and compositional landscape heterogeneity. At a global scale, agriculture practiced under smallholder dominated landscapes, and not large-scale farming, is the backbone of global food security. In conclusion, linking agricultural intensification with biodiversity conservation and hunger reduction requires well-informed regional solutions at different spatial scales.

Recorded for the AgroEcoWeb Conference, Brazil 2017.

Website of Prof. Dr. Teja Tscharntke: 
https://www.uni-goettingen.de/de/92552.html

title: Jedes Tier - eine Idee: Der K√ºnstler Ammar Hatem
description:
K√ºnstler zu werden, war ein Traum von Ammar Hatem. Jetzt malt der Syrer in G√∂ttingen - vor allem Wale und Delfine. Die Tierwelt geh√∂rt zu seinen bevorzugten Motiven. Im Zoologischen Museum der Uni G√∂ttingen finden diese einen geeigneten Platz: Ammars neuestes Werk ‚ÄûAus der Erde‚Äú wird neben dem ‚ÄûG√∂ttinger Pottwal‚Äú gezeigt, dem 17 Meter langen Skelett eines Pottwalbullens. 
Die Ausstellung ‚ÄûAus der Erde‚Äú wird am Sonntag, 15. Oktober 2017, er√∂ffnet. Der Kustos des Museums, Dr. Gert Tr√∂ster, pr√§sentiert das Mixed Media-Werk des syrischen K√ºnstlers. Die Matinee beginnt um 11 Uhr an der Berliner Stra√üe 28.

title: Panel Discussion Positioning & power in academic publishing
description:
Panel Discussion: Positioning and power in academic publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas, Moderation: Wolfram Horstmann, SUB G√∂ttingen, Guests: Clifford Lynch, Coalition for Networked Information (CNI), Niels Stern, Nordic Council of Ministers, Andrea Polle, B√ºsgen-Institut, Universit√§t G√∂ttingen, Andreas Degwitz, Humboldt University Berlin, DINI, Mike Mertens, DARIAH-EU, Laura Henderson, Frontiers
Held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

title: Insights from over a decade Electronic Publishing Research
description:
Insights from over a decade of Electronic Publishing Research, Fernando Loizides, University of Wolverhampton
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 8 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Data mining and knowledge discovery, Session Chair: Pierre Mournier
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: The work in this article presents findings from a text mining exercise of over a decade of research into electronic publication. We give readers insights into the past, present and possible future directions in a structured way, and further allowing them access to the extracted data in order to produce their own analysis and conclusion. We also produce our working methodology which can be replicated to produce systematic similar findings over the years as well as comparisons to other data sources.

title: Subirats Coll: Controlled vocabularies and PHAIDRA Int.
description:
Controlled vocabularies and PHAIDRA International, Imma Subirats Coll, FAO of the United Nations
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 8 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Data mining and knowledge discovery, Session Chair: Pierre Mournier
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Following the COAR-SPARC conference in Porto, the COAR Controlled Vocabularies Interest Group met on the 16th of April 2015 and had a detailed discussion about the new set of COAR controlled vocabularies, while proposing detailed actions to solve the remaining issues (mainly in the Resource Type vocabulary). Echoing aspects discussed about sustainability and organization (long-term technical support), as well as dissemination and implementation of COAR controlled vocabularies, the immediate projection of these issues has seemed to be quite feasible on PHAIDRA International long-term ecosystem. Nowadays this OAI-PMH environment consists of fourteen Open Access repositories disseminating their contents to EUROPEANA, OpenAIRE, OAPENLibrary, e-infrastructures Austria, and national CRIS etc. PHAIDRA International is taking all necessary steps to be constantly aligned with Trusted Digital Repositories criteria and harmonized (technically and semantically) in line with COAR Roadmap: Future Directions for Repository Interoperability. The COAR Roadmap stresses that still many challenges remain with improving interoperability. These involve standardization of controlled vocabularies in use, as well as metadata and indicators, in connection with state-of-the-art interoperability approaches supporting Linked Open Data. There is an urgent need for PHAIDRA International to harmonize the encoding description (metadata properties) according to LOD-enabling strategies, and to adhere to multilingual COAR controlled vocabularies‚Äù shared registry (Knowledge Base) services. COAR Controlled Vocabularies can be easily implemented in PHAIDRA in fixed formats and mapped to related persistent RDF/SKOS versions.

title: Referencing of complex software environments
description:
Referencing of complex software environments as representations of research data, Sven Bingert, GWDG, Stefan Buddenbohm, Georg-August-Universit√§t G√∂ttingen
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 8 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Data mining and knowledge discovery, Session Chair: Pierre Mournier
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Complex software environments, like virtual research environments or visualization frameworks, are increasingly used to conduct research and present its results. While there is a growing amount for solutions facilitating the (granular) citation of publications and research data, the citation of complex software environments remains a challenge. This abstract outlines the challenges and introduces an approach for referencing software environments developed in the Humanities Data Centre project: the application preservation.

title: Maria Eskevich: Stakeholders in academic publishing
description:
Stakeholders in academic publishing: Text and data mining perspective and potential, Maria Eskevich, Radboud University
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 8 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Data mining and knowledge discovery, Session Chair: Pierre Mournier
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: In this paper we discuss the concept of open access in academic publishing with the focus on the right to mine the data once the right to read is granted. Thus we envisage the roles and types of the stakeholders in academic publishing from the perspective of the potential text and data mining (TDM) applications. Further on, we briefly introduce FutureTDM project that aims to improve TDM uptake in Europe.

title: Chris Penfold: A new model for open access university presses
description:
UCL Press: a new model for open access university presses, Chris Penfold, UCL Press
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 7 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Stakeholders and their positions, Session Chair: Margo Bargheer
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: UCL Press was relaunched at UCL in June 2015, as the UK‚Äôs first fully open access university press. It publishes scholarly monographs, textbooks, edited collections, scholarly editions and journals. All publications are made freely available online in open access form and print books are also sold via retailers at an affordable price. UCL authors are funded to publish open access with the Press. This article describes its activities in more detail and offers the model as one that other institutions can follow.

title: Gerald Beasley: APCs: a new route to Open Access?
description:
Article Processing Charges: a new route to Open Access?, Gerald Beasley, University of Alberta, Canada
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 7 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Stakeholders and their positions, Session Chair: Margo Bargheer
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Article Processing Charges (APCs) have recently been studied as a means towards a sustainable Open Access (OA) environment for scholarly communications. However, APCs at any level represent a substantial economic barrier to the authors, institutions, funding agencies and governments that many of its advocates most wish to serve through OA initiatives.

title: Stone: Sustaining the growth of library scholarly publishing
description:
Sustaining the growth of library scholarly publishing, Graham Stone, University of Huddersfield
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library. 

Session 7 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Stakeholders and their positions, Session Chair: Margo Bargheer
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: 
In 2012, the University of Huddersfield Press presented a paper at the 16th International Conference on Electronic Publishing on its new open access journals platform. At the time, the Press was one of the only New University Presses (NUP) in the UK and one of the first to publish open access journals, open access monographs and sound recordings. This paper will develop Hahn‚Äôs programme and publication level business plan and relate this to the sustainability of the Press. It will demonstrate how the Press has been able to show value to the University in order to secure funding. The paper will conclude with a discussion around the need for collaboration between library led NUPs.

title: Schmidt, Kuchma: Librarians‚Äô new skills and competencies
description:
Time to adopt: Librarians‚Äô new skills and competency profiles, Birgit Schmidt, Georg-August-Universit√§t G√∂ttingen, Iryna Kuchma, EIFL
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library. 

Session 7 (9 June 2016, 11.15 ‚Äì 12.45), Stakeholders and their positions,
Session Chair: Margo Bargheer
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: 
On the one hand, libraries are at the forefront of the digital transformation and digital information infrastructures, on the other, they manage and curate cultural heritage collections. This brings about new ways of engagement with information and knowledge and the need to rethink skills and competency profiles ‚Äì which enable librarians to support e-research all along the research cycle. This paper presents findings of the joint Task Force on Librarians‚Äô Competencies in Support of E-Research and Scholarly Communication.

title: Prateek Mahalwar: Early career Researchers and Open Access
description:
Early career Researchers and Open Access, Prateek Mahalwar, Max Planck Society
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 6 (9 June 2016, 09.00 ‚Äì 10.45)
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Prateek Mahalwar shares with us his views on opportunities and challenges for early career researchers in the context of Open Science

title: Gu√©don: Whither Open Access? Four scenarios and four choices
description:
Whither Open Access? Four scenarios and four choices, Jean-Claude Gu√©don, University of Montr√©al
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 6 (9 June 2016, 09.00 ‚Äì 10.45)
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Because we tend to look at the future through our rear-view mirrors, we tend to treat electronic publishing as a simple transposition of print. The late 15th century played the same trick on manuscripts. This mindset has led to a first phase of electronic documents that have been correctly characterized as "digital incunabula" (G. Crane). We are now entering a second, more crucial, phase where the very rise of open access acts as a symptom of the experienced changes: Because electronic documents do not behave, circulate or work like printed documents, issues like access are being foregrounded. However, the evolution of open access has also revealed important fault lines between various actors who hold divergent agendas. Predictably, the transition is neither smooth nor simple. We may ask, therefore: Whither Open Access? The future of Open Access will compound a number of different perspectives. Here, we shall explore four of them: the researchers, the librarians, the funders, and the publishers. The form Open Access will ultimately take cannot be predicted, but each one of us can have a clearer view of the available choices.

title: Ghavimi: Identifying dataset references in social sciences
description:
Identifying and improving dataset references in social sciences full Texts, Behnam Ghavimi, GESIS
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 5 (8 June 2016, 15.30 ‚Äì 17.00), Full Paper Presentations, Session Chair: Leslie Chan
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Scientific full text papers are usually stored in separate places than their underlying research datasets. Authors typically make references to datasets by mentioning them for example by using their titles and the year of publication. However, in most cases explicit links that would provide readers with direct access to referenced datasets are missing. Manually detecting references to datasets in papers is time consuming and requires an expert in the domain of the paper. In order to make explicit all links to datasets in papers that have been published already, we suggest and evaluate a semi-automatic approach for finding references to datasets in social sciences papers. Our approach does not need a corpus of papers (no cold start problem) and it performs well on a small test corpus (gold standard). Our approach achieved an F-measure of 0.84 for identifying references in full texts and an F-measure of 0.83 for finding correct matches of detected references in the da|ra dataset registry.

title: Ross-Hellauer: Peer Review on the move from closed to open
description:
Peer Review on the move from closed to open, Anthony Ross-Hellauer, Georg-August-Universit√§t G√∂ttingen, OpenAIRE
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library. 

Session 5 (8 June 2016, 15.30 ‚Äì 17.00), Full Paper Presentations, Session Chair: Leslie Chan
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Openness in peer review is no longer a terra incognita. However, there remains a need for further experimentation and careful evaluation of its advantages and disadvantages in practice. OpenAIRE, the European digital infrastructure for Open Scholarship, offers a unique environment for such experiments. This paper describes the design and early results of three such experiments, which are currently under development in close collaboration with selected publishing and repository communities.

title: Valentina Moscon: Open Access, Open Science, Open Society
description:
Open Access, Open Science, Open Society, Valentina Moscon, Max-Planck-Institute for Innovation and Competition
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library. 

Session 5 (8 June 2016, 15.30 ‚Äì 17.00), Full Paper Presentations, Session Chair: Leslie Chan
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Open Access‚Äô main goal is not the subversion of publishers‚Äô role as driving actors in an oligopolistic market characterized by reduced competition and higher prices. OA‚Äôs main function is to be found somewhere else, namely in the ability to subvert the power to control science‚Äôs governance and its future directions (Open Science), a power that is more often found within the academic institutions rather than outside. By decentralizing and opening-up not just the way in which scholarship is published but also the way in which it is assessed, OA removes the barriers that helped turn science into an intellectual oligopoly even before an economic one. The goal of this paper is to demonstrate that Open Access is a key enabler of Open Science, which in turn will lead to a more Open Society. Furthermore, the paper argues that while legislative interventions play an important role in the top-down regulation of Open Access, legislators currently lack an informed and systematic vision on the role of Open Access in science and society. In this historical phase, other complementary forms of intervention (bottom-up) appear much more ‚Äúinformed‚Äù and effective. This paper, which intends to set the stage for future research, identifies a few pieces of the puzzle: the relationship between formal and informal norms in the field of Open Science and how this impact on intellectual property rights, the protection of personal data, the assessment of science and the technology employed for the communication of science.

title: Xenia Van Edig: Interactive Public Peer ReviewTM
description:
Interactive Public Peer ReviewTM: an innovative approach to scientific quality assurance, Xenia Van Edig, Copernicus GmbH
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library. 

Session 4 (8 June 2016, 13.30 - 15.00), Maintaining quality over time, Session Chair: Niels Stern
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Besides providing open access to the article, Copernicus Publications provides open access to the peer review via its Interactive Public Peer Review‚Ñ¢. In this process, a public discussion among the author, two independent referees, and interested members of the scientific community builds the core of the peer review process.

title: Bernd Kulawik: If there are documents you really care about
description:
If there are documents you really care about: Print them out! Bernd Kulawik, Stiftung Bibliothek Werner Oechslin
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 4 (8 June 2016, 13.30 - 15.00), Maintaining quality over time, Session Chair: Niels Stern
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: With these words (only ‚Äúdocuments‚Äù substituted for the original ‚Äúphotos‚Äù) Vint Cerf, one of the ‚Äòfathers of the internet‚Äô and now Google Vice President, warned in 2015 that all our photos ‚Äì and obviously, documents and research data, too ‚Äì might disappear soon and that our century may become the ‚ÄúDigital Dark Age‚Äù. To avoid this, Cerf is working on a solution named ‚Äúdigital vellum‚Äù: It shall provide a platform that can preserve any documents, the software used to create and work with them, the operating system needed for this software and even an emulation of the appropriate hardware. But it may take quite some time before this platform will be available. In the meantime, the good old paper is the only medium that surely can and will survive more than 50 years ‚Äì the maximum now expected for simple formats like .txt and .pdf files. Even Microfilms (also not usable without technical means) may not survive more than 200 years. But how do we print out digital documents created for and by research: short miscellanea, articles and papers, collections of them and monographs, and in recent years even facebook postings or twitter messages? We write these documents in a dedicated (text) program, sent them to the publisher, who may forward them after several transmissions forth and back with the author(s) to a layouter, again followed by some corrections requiring exchange of the file(s) ‚Ä¶ and finally they may appear in print and / or online repositories. Taking into account that all participants in the process today are (or should be) well familiar with web-based Content Management Systems and ‚Äì hopefully ‚Äì the concept of markup languages, it is simply astonishing that there is no system yet combining the advantages of both. Such a combination could not only serve to shorten the publishing process but also provide the ecosystem for online repositories and webbased collaboration while the results ‚Äì printable documents ‚Äì could be updated regularly and made available via book-on-demand and as ePublications. There may be some solutions providing such a system used by publishers ‚Äúin-house‚Äù, but if so, they are not available for free. The paper will propose such a system based on Free and Open Source Software with a simple proof-of-concept.

title: Astrid Orth: FOSTER‚Äôs training tools and best practices
description:
FOSTER‚Äôs Open Science training tools and best practices, Astrid Orth, Georg-August-Universit√§t G√∂ttingen
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library. 

Session 4 (8 June 2016, 13.30 - 15.00), Maintaining quality over time, 
Session Chair: Niels Stern
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: FOSTER is an EU project aiming at identifying, enriching and providing training content on relevant Open Science topics in support of implementing EC‚Äòs Open Science Agenda in the European Research Area. During the previous two years a wealth of training resources have been collected, which are now presented in a dedicated training portal. The paper describes how to use the FOSTER training platform and the tools available to identify suitable training materials and create modular e-learning courses.

title: Laurence Mabile: Towards new metrics for bioresources use
description:
Towards new metrics for bioresources use, Laurence Mabile, INSERM ‚Äì Universit√© Toulouse III
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library. 

Session 3 (8 June 2016, 13.30 ‚Äì 15.00), Disciplinary approaches:  A model for all? 
Session Chair: Peter Linde
Further information: http://elpub.net/

The BRIF is an ongoing initiative that encompasses reflections and actions from various stakeholders (researchers, funders, industrials, editors) towards 
1. standardised identification schemes and reporting for better visibility and tracing of bioresources on the web; 
2. incentive policies from hosting institutions; 
3. creation of tools allowing follow up of their use. 
Tracing the use of bioresource is the first step in this process and for this purpose we have published the CoBRA (Citation of BioResources in journal Articles) guideline, launched the Open Journal of Bioresources and started developing new metrics. The CoBRA guideline aims to standardise the citation of bioresources in scientific articles in order to trace their use on the web. The Open Journal of Bioresources (OJB) was created in close collaboration with the open access publisher Ubiquity Press allowing both the resources and the OJB papers to be cited, and also providing authors with tools to get metrics on reuse and impact. New better adapted metrics are being worked out in a dedicated BRIF working subgroup. A first list of relevant parameters to take into account in the impact measure of bioresources has been provided. The tools proposed here foster easier access to samples and associated data as well as their optimised use, sharing and recognition for data producers. Input from the scientific editorial community would be highly appreciated at this stage.

title: Fiona Nielsen: Genome sharing projects around the world
description:
Genome sharing projects around the world: How you find data for your research, Fiona Nielsen, Repositive
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 3 (8 June 2016, 13.30 ‚Äì 15.00), Disciplinary approaches: A model for all? Session Chair: Peter Linde
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: Access to raw experimental research data and data reuse is a common hurdle in scientific research. Despite the mounting requirements from funding agencies that the raw data is deposited as soon as (or even before) the paper is published, multiple factors often prevent data from being accessed and reused by other researchers. The situation with the human genomic data is even more dramatic, since on the one hand human genomic data is probably the most important data to share - it lies at the heart of efforts to combat major health issues such as cancer, genetic diseases, and genetic predispositions for complex diseases like heart disease and diabetes. On the other hand, since it is sensitive and personal information, it is often exempt from data sharing requirements. DNAdigest investigates the barriers for ethical and efficient genomic data sharing and engages with all stakeholder groups, including researchers, librarians, data managers, software developers, policy makers, and the general public interested in genomics. Repositive offers services and tools that reduce the barriers for data access and reuse for the research community in academia, industry, and clinics. To address the most pressing problem for public genomic data: that of data discoverability, Repositive has built an online platform (repositive.io) providing a single point of entry to find and access available genomic research data.

title: Tara Andrews: Digital scholarship and publication ecosystem
description:
After the spring: Digital forms of scholarship and the publication ecosystem, Tara Andrews, University of Bern
Lecture held during the 20th International Conference on Electronic Publishing entitled "Positioning and Power in Academic Publishing: Players, Agents and Agendas", June 7-9 2016 at G√∂ttingen State and University Library.

Session 2 (8 June 2016, 11.00 ‚Äì 11.45),
Further information: http://elpub.net/

Abstract: How do you cite a database query? Which academic publisher will be the first to accept a Jupyter notebook as a journal article? One of the great promises of the digital medium has been that it would revolutionise the established forms academic publishing. Over the last few years we have seen a somewhat different form of revolution, however; the awareness that the traditional system for academic publication is deeply flawed has taken hold in the consciousness of academics throughout the world, but publication is still usually understood in terms of journal articles, edited collections, and monographs. The uprising against the established business model for academic publication has provided us with an opportune moment to take stock of the other revolution. In this talk I will look at some forms of publication that I believe will be critical to digitally-enabled science and scholarship, and consider from the perspective of a researcher what sort of publishing ecosystem might meet our needs.

title: 20 years Elpub: A glimpse into its past, present and future

20 years Elpub: A glimpse into its past, present and future, Leslie Chan, Sely Costa, Jean-Claude Gu√©don, Olivia Holmes, Peter Linde

Veranstaltung der Kinder-Uni im Sommersemester 2017. Lehrende und Studierende gestalten gemeinsam eine Vorlesung an der Uni G√∂ttingen: Wissenschaft f√ºr Kinder! Verst√§ndlich und unterhaltsam.

title: Karlstadt: Reformator des 16. Jahrhunderts
description:
Prof. Dr. Thomas Kaufmann spricht √ºber den bedeutenden Reformator des 16. Jahrhunderts. Etwa 70 gedruckte Werke in √ºber 200 Ausgaben bezeugen seinen Einfluss als Theologe und Publizist der Reformation. Die ersten beiden B√§nde der kritischen Karlstadt-Edition sind am 26. April 2017 erschienen.
Das DFG-Langzeitprojekt "Kritische Gesamtausgabe der Schriften und Briefe Andreas Bodensteins von Karlstadt" wird von der Akademie der Wissenschaften zu G√∂ttingen betreut. Ziel des Projektes, das 2012 unter dem Dach der Universit√§t G√∂ttingen seine Arbeit aufgenommen hat, ist eine Werkausgabe aller Schriften und Briefe von Andreas Bodenstein von Karlstadt (1486-1541) in digitaler und gedruckter Form. Die digitale Edition entsteht in Kooperation mit der Herzog-August-Bibliothek Wolfenb√ºttel. 

On April 26, 2017, the Edition officially celebrated the publication of the first two volumes of the Karlstadt Critical Edition in conjunction with the 500th Anniversary of the posting of Karlstadt‚Äôs 151 Thesen. The volumes (KGK I/1 and I/2), available through G√ºtersloher Verlagshaus, include Karlstadt‚Äôs letters and writings from 1507-1518 and constitute a monumental new resource for Reformation research.

description:

title: Die G√∂ttinger Erkl√§rung 1957
description:
1957 brachte ein Ereignis den Namen G√∂ttingens weltweit in die Schlagzeilen: die am 12. April des Jahres ver√∂ffentlichte ‚ÄûG√∂ttinger Erkl√§rung‚Äú. Die Mitte der f√ºnfziger Jahre betriebene Ausstattung der US-Truppen mit taktischen Atomwaffen f√ºhrte im Laufe des Jahres 1956 in der Bundesrepublik zu einer immer heftiger werdenden Diskussion √ºber √§hnliche Pl√§ne in der neugegr√ºndeten Bundeswehr. Als der bisherige Atomministers Franz Josef Strau√ü zum Verteidigungsminister ernannt wurde und Bundeskanzler Konrad Adenauer im April 1957 in einer Presseerkl√§rung die atomare Aufr√ºstung verharmloste, formierte sich Widerstand.

Auf Anregung Carl Friedrich von Weizs√§ckers schlossen sich 18 Atomwissenschaftler ‚Äì unter ihnen Max Born, Otto Hahn und Werner Heisenberg ‚Äì zusammen. In einer √∂ffentlichen Erkl√§rung forderten sie, auf eine atomare Bewaffnung der Bundeswehr zu verzichten  und die Bev√∂lkerung √ºber die Gefahren von Atomwaffen aufzukl√§ren.

Zeitzeugen und Wissenschaftler erinnern an das Ereignis und an die Verantwortung von Wissenschaft gegen√ºber der Gesellschaft.
Die Interviews entstanden  am 3. Mai 2017 im Rahmen der Festveranstaltung zum 60. Jahrestag der G√∂ttinger Erkl√§rung, die von der Universit√§t G√∂ttingen, der Vereinigung Deutscher Wissenschaftler e.V. (VDW) und der Deutschen Physikalischen Gesellschaft e.V. (DPG) organisiert wurde.

Weitere Informationen sind unter https://www.uni-goettingen.de/de/die+g%C3%B6ttinger+erkl%C3%A4rung+1957/54319.html zu finden.

title: HASCO Summer School 2017
description:
The main objectives of the hadron collider physics school (HASCO) are introductory topics in elementary particle physics, in particular in hadron collider physics as relevant for research at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). This includes lectures and tutorials on theoretical foundations of the Standard Model of elementary particle physics as well as experimental techniques to test it. This year's focus was placed on physics of the Higgs boson, which was discovered on 4th July 2012, and of the upcoming 13/14 TeV energy. Almost 60 students and 12 lecturers from 12 institutes in Germany, Belgium, Netherlands, Norway, Italy, Poland, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom as well as the United States, Nepal and Japan attended the school from 16.7.-21.7.2017 with lectures and tutorials.
More information at http://hasco.uni-goettingen.de

title: Science Me! 2017: 3-2-1 Fire - Physics + Chemistry
description:
Matthias De Bot + Marlie Van Gils, Belgium.
Science is exciting! Science is big and Science is fun! 
During the 2nd edition of Science Me, Science-Show-Teams from all over Europe came together in Hanover during the Ideen Expo 2017.¬´ Science Me! ¬ª, the European Science Show Competition, is aimed at strengthening the dialogue between scientists and the general public. Organized this time around by the Georg-August-University of G√∂ttingen, spectators had the chance to watch entertaining and educational shows. 10-minute presentations in all fields of science or technology consisting of experiments, demonstrations or explanations, given by a maximum of 2 animators, are evaluated by the public and by an independent jury of experts in science and communication. 
As an essential science dialogue tool, ¬´ Science Me! ¬ª, the European Championship of Science Shows, is an innovative instrument offering to the general audience the possibility to evaluate at the measuring rod of their own sensitivity and understanding. Short presentations in all fields of science or technology are given in a playful and interactive manner. 
If you are interested yourself now, check out the videos from the different presentations and of course the final in our channel! And see you at the next Science Me!

title: Bundespr√§sident Steinmeier besucht die Universit√§t G√∂ttingen
description:
Bundespr√§sident Frank-Walter Steinmeier hat auf seiner Antrittsreise in Niedersachsen die Universit√§t G√∂ttingen besucht. In der Aula am Wilhelmsplatz hielt er eine Ansprache und nahm an einer Podiumsdiskussion zum Thema ‚ÄûDemokratie ‚Äì Wissenschaft ‚Äì Verantwortung‚Äú teil.
Welche Verantwortung tragen Wissenschaft und Universit√§ten f√ºr die Zukunft der Zivilgesellschaft und die Gestaltung der Demokratie? Welchen Beitrag k√∂nnen Wissenschaftlerinnen und Wissenschaftler leisten, um das Vertrauen in demokratische Prozesse zu st√§rken? Wie kann und muss Wissenschaft transparent arbeiten und Erkenntnisse aktiv in die √ñffentlichkeit vermitteln? Diese und √§hnliche Fragen standen im Fokus der Podiumsdiskussion, an der neben Steinmeier auch Prof. Dr. Dirk Schumann, Seminar f√ºr Mittlere und Neuere Geschichte, Dr. Stine Marg, Gesch√§ftsf√ºhrende Leiterin des Instituts f√ºr Demokratieforschung, die G√∂ttinger AStA-Vorsitzende Silke Hansmann und Matthias Jakubowski von der ‚ÄûRefugee Law Clinic‚Äú der Universit√§t G√∂ttingen teilnehmen. Moderiert wurde die Diskussion von Dr. Wilhelm Krull, Vorsitzender des Stiftungsrates der Universit√§t G√∂ttingen.
Prof. Dr. Ulrike Beisiegel, Pr√§sidentin der Universit√§t G√∂ttingen, begr√º√üte die G√§ste und er√∂ffnete die Veranstaltung.

description: Wer nat√ºrlich vorkommende Energiequellen wie das Sonnenlicht nutzen m√∂chte, muss das Licht zun√§chst einfangen und entweder in Form von elektrischer Leistung an  das Verbundnetz abgeben oder speichern. In diesen Umwandlungsprozessen geht unvermeidlich Energie verloren. Um solche Verluste m√∂glichst klein zu halten, untersuchen Wissenschaftlerinnen und Wissenschaftler des SFB 1073 an der Universit√§t G√∂ttingen die Umwandlung von Energie auf atomarer Skala. Durch ein solches Verst√§ndnis erhoffen sie sich, neue Strategien f√ºr hocheffiziente Energiesysteme zu finden. Dazu ist es aber nicht nur notwendig, dass Forschende mit unterschiedlichen Kompetenzen zusammenarbeiten,  es m√ºssen auch Untersuchungsmethoden eingesetzt und weiterentwickelt werden, die Beobachtungen auf atomaren Dimensionen erm√∂glichen.

title: Zauberhafte Physik: Stern-Gerlach-Experiment
description:
Woher wissen wir, dass Elektronen einen Eigendrehimpuls = Spin 1/2 haben und was bedeutet das? Die Antwort ist das Stern-Gerlach-Experiment, ein historisches Schl√ºsselexperiment.
Das im Jahr 1922 von Otto Stern und Walther Gerlach durchgef√ºhrte Experiment zeigt, dass Silber- oder Kalium-Atome sich beim Flug durch ein inhomogenes Magnetfeld in zwei Teilstrahlen aufteilen. Der Drehimpuls der Atome und daraus resultierend deren magnetisches Moment werden nur durch den Eigendrehimpuls=Spin des Elektrons in der √§u√üeren Elektronenschale gebildet. Diese Beobachtung l√§sst sich nur durch die Spin-Quantisierung entlang des magnetischen Feldes interpretieren. Das Ergebnis zeigt auch, dass der Spin entlang dieser Richtung die Werte +1/2 oder -1/2 annimmt und somit der Spin selber den Wert 1/2 besitzt. Man nennt Teilchen mit halbzahligem Spin auch "Fermionen". Der Clip veranschaulicht das Ph√§nomen und erl√§utert die Zusammenh√§nge.
Mehr Infos unter http://physikshow.uni-goettingen.de.

title: Vom philosophischen Schulbetrieb zum kirchlichen Katechumenat
description:
Die G√∂ttinger Theologen und Kirchenhistoriker Prof. Dr. Peter Gemeinhardt und Prof. Dr. Tobias Georges sprechen √ºber ‚ÄûVom philosophischen Schulbetrieb zum kirchlichen Katechumenat: Institutionalisierungen religi√∂ser Bildung im sp√§tantiken Christentum‚Äú.
Religi√∂se Bildung¬†pr√§gt das Denken und Handeln der fr√ºhen Christen zutiefst.¬†Bereits im sog. Taufbefehl Jesu ist angelegt, Menschen √ºber den Glauben zu belehren und sie in den Stand zu versetzen, sich f√ºr (oder auch gegen) die Zugeh√∂rigkeit zum Christentum zu entscheiden. Wie wurde das aber konkret umgesetzt? Welche Institutionen entwickelten sich in den ersten Jahrhunderten n. Chr., und wer waren die Akteure? √úber diese und weitere Fragen f√ºhren die G√∂ttinger Kirchenhistoriker Tobias Georges und Peter Gemeinhardt ein Gespr√§ch. Sie beginnen mit den christlich-philosophischen Schulen im 2. und 3. Jahrhundert und zeichnen die Entwicklung bis zum bisch√∂flich geleiteten Katechumenat des 4. und 5. Jahrhunderts nach. Was Lehrer, Katecheten und Bisch√∂fe "machen" k√∂nnen, um Menschen zum Glauben zu bringen, wird ins Verh√§ltnis zu Gott als beteiligtem Akteur gesetzt - dabei wird je und je auch die theologische Theorie mit der beobachtbaren Praxis abgeglichen. Das Christentum erweist sich von Anbeginn an als eine Bildungsreligion - mit einer erstaunlichen Pluralit√§t von Bildungsinstitutionen.

Aufzeichnung im Rahmen der √∂ffentlichen Vortragsreihe ‚Äû¬ªDas Paradies ist ein H√∂rsaal f√ºr die Seelen.¬´ Institutionen religi√∂ser Bildung in historischer Perspektive‚Äú am 7. Dezember 2016 im Alfred-Hessel-Saal im Historischen Geb√§ude der Staats- und Universit√§tsbibliothek G√∂ttingen.

title: Origenes‚Äô Bibliotheks- und Lehrinstitut in Caesarea
description:
Die Arch√§ologin Dr. Balbina B√§bler, wissenschaftliche Mitarbeiterin im Sonderforschungsbereich 1136 ‚ÄûBildung und Religion‚Äú an der Universit√§t G√∂ttingen, spricht √ºber ‚ÄûF√ºr Christen und Heiden, M√§nner und Frauen: Origenes‚Äô Bibliotheks- und Lehrinstitut in Caesarea‚Äú.
Der Vortrag befasst sich mit dem Kirchenvater Origenes (um 185‚Äì253) und seiner Schule und Bibliothek in Caesarea Maritima (im heutigen Israel). Origenes verbrachte seiner Jugend in der multikulturellen, multireligi√∂sen Weltstadt Alexandria, wo er nach dem M√§rtyrertod seines Vaters 202/3 eine Lehrt√§tigkeit an der sogenannten ‚ÄûKatechetenschule‚Äú aufnahm und ein Philosophiestudium bei dem Neuplatoniker Ammonios Sakkas absolvierte.
231/1 emigrierte er nach Caesarea, wo er sein ‚ÄûBibliotheks- und Lehrinstitut‚Äú aufbaute, das die Stadt zum intellektuellen Zentrum des fr√ºhen Christentums machte. Grundlage seines Unterrichts war die Auseinandersetzung mit nahezu allen philosophischen Richtungen als Vorbereitung f√ºr das Studium der heiligen Schrift. Origenes f√ºhrte die Methoden der alexandrinischen Philologie in die Bibelkommentierung ein. Er setzte sich auch mit der j√ºdischen Bibelinterpretation auseinander und f√ºhrte Gespr√§che mit den j√ºdischen Gelehrten von Caesarea. Zu seiner umfangreichen, unter seinen Nachfolgern Pamphilos und Eusebius weiter ausgebauten Bibliothek geh√∂rte auch ein Scriptorium, in dem u.a. die Hexapla, eine Synopse des hebr√§ischen Bibeltexts mit Transkription und vier griechischen √úbersetzungen, hergestellt wurde. 
Origenes‚Äô Institution blieb f√ºr Jahrhunderte ber√ºhmt, konnte aber bis heute arch√§ologisch nicht nachgewiesen werden. 

Aufzeichnung im Rahmen der √∂ffentlichen Vortragsreihe ‚Äû¬ªDas Paradies ist ein H√∂rsaal f√ºr die Seelen.¬´ Institutionen religi√∂ser Bildung in historischer Perspektive‚Äú am 30. November 2016 im Alfred-Hessel-Saal im Historischen Geb√§ude der Staats- und Universit√§tsbibliothek G√∂ttingen.

title: Women and the Reformation
description:
Prof. Dr. Albrecht Classen, University of Arizona, about ‚ÄûWomen and the Reformation: Audacious and Feisty Voices from Sixteenth-Century Germany‚Äú. This guest lecture was held on June 29, 2016, at the Faculty of Theology, University of G√∂ttingen, as part of the M.A. programme "Intercultural Theology.
Dr. Albrecht Classen is University Distinguished Professor at the University of Arizona, Department of German Studies. He studied at the universities of Marburg, Erlangen (Germany), Millersville, PA (USA), Oxford (Great Britain), Salamanca (Spain), Urbino (Italy), and Charlottesville, VA (USA). He received his Ph.D. from the University of Virginia in 1986. He has a broad range of research interests covering the history of medieval and early modern German and European literature and culture from about 800 to 1800. He has published more than 85 scholarly books, including monographs, critical editions, translations, and textbooks, more than 600 scholarly articles, and 9 volumes of his own poetry (in German). He is the editor of the journal Mediaevistik and the online journal Humanities Open Access http://www.mdpi.com/journal/humanities. He has also contributed to the website www.frauen-und-reformation.de, specifically: http://frauen-und-reformation.de/?s=bio&id=74 which contains about 150 biographies of Reformation women from the 15th to the 20th century. 
In 2017 we are going to celebrate the 500th Anniversary of Martin Luther‚Äôs 95 theses, the beginning of the Protestant Reformation. Truly a monumental event in western history. But was it only a history initiated and carried by men? Yes, at first sight, if we are thinking of such giants next to Luther as Philipp Melanchthon, Ulrich Zwingli, John Calvin, Martin Bucer, Johannes Bugenhagen, etc. But no, if we take a second look. In fact, we can identify numerous women who emerged as part of the Protestant Reformation and made their voices heard, primary among them the Bavarian noble lady Argula von Grumbach. Her broadsheets, letters, and missives from the years 1522 and 1523 were hailed far and wide as deeply learned in Scripture and highly convincing in rhetoric. Well known is also Luther‚Äôs own wife, Katharina von Bora, without whom he would not have been able to carry out his countless daily businesses. Katharina Zell, wife of the Strassburg minister Matthew Zell, likewise became highly active in writing Protestant texts, parallel to Katharina von M√ºnsterberg, and others. At the end of the sixteenth century, the major religious poet Anna Ovena Hoyers raised her voice, this time against Protestant clergy, which met a lot of criticism, and she was eventually even exiled, but her texts could not be repressed. The same applies to Anna Maria van Schurman, a seventeenth-century intellectual turned Labadist. This talk introduces some of the major female players from the era of the Protestant Reformation and provides a refreshing counter-balance to a traditional male perspective.

Further information:
‚Ä¢ M.A. programme "Intercultural Theology": https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/109075.html
‚Ä¢ Project ‚ÄúInternationalization of the Curricula‚Äù http://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/530455.html
‚Ä¢ Theological Faculty of Georg-August-Universit√§t G√∂ttingen https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/19855.html
‚Ä¢ University of Applied Sciences for Intercultural Theology Hermannsburg http://www.fh-hermannsburg-eng.landeskirche-hannovers.de/
‚Ä¢ Prof. Dr. Albrecht Classen http://aclassen.faculty.arizona.edu/

Further links to women and the Reformation:
‚Ä¢ http://www.frauen-und-reformation.de (available in German only)

title: Student Uprisings and the Political University: Perspectives from India (Roundtable discussion)
description:
2 June 2016, University of G√∂ttingen: Over the past year, university campuses across India have witnessed a series of intense and protracted student protests. Although decisions taken by the university administration have been the immediate target, the protests have been galvanized by a far wider set of sociopolitical concerns, ranging from caste and gender discrimination to the privatization of higher education and the concerted assault on democratic rights and freedoms by political authorities. The increasingly authoritarian tendencies of state power stand have been exposed in the fraught space of the contemporary Indian university. At the same time, the university is also a place of active democratic experimentation and transformation, where student movements are forging solidarities across existing divisions of ideology and identity and building a new politics of hope and struggle. To understand the significance of student uprisings and the "political university" in the context of similar struggles that are unfolding in universities from South Africa to the United States, CeMIS hosted a roundtable discussion. Three senior scholars (Professors Neeladri Bhattacharya, Ayesha Kidwai and Janaki Nair) with first-hand experience of the recent events at Delhi's Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), presented their reflections to a public audience. The conversation was moderated by CeMIS faculty members, Prof. Ravi Ahuja and Prof. Srirupa Roy. 

Find out more about CeMIS at: 
http://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/131257.html

title: Can you read my mind?
description:
As humans we are pretty good at telling what other people think and predicting what they will do next. If your partner reaches out his arm over the breakfast table you know that he wants to get the butter rather than to exercise his biceps. Knowing what others want helps us cope in everyday life: we know when other people are in need of help and we know when somebody is going to get aggressive so we can run away in time. But do we do this implicitly, without even thinking about it? Or is predicting what other people will do actually a complicated mental exercise? This talk summarizes facts from recent research to shed light on how we read other people‚Äôs minds.

4. Juli 2016: Dr. Louisa Kulke, Cognitive Developmental Psychology, G√∂ttingen

More information:  https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/539996.html

title: Saying more or less what you think
description:
When communicating with each other, we speak in sentences. But how do we know what a sentence means? Everybody will agree that the meaning of a sentence follows from the meaning of its words, and how these words are ordered. After all, the sentence ‚ÄòMary loves John‚Äô cannot all of the sudden mean that Bill bought a cake. However, sometimes we say more than we mean. Why do we say ‚ÄòJohn walk-s‚Äô and not just ‚ÄòJohn walk‚Äô? The ‚Äìs in ‚ÄòJohn walk-s‚Äô is fully superfluous. On the other hand, sometimes we say less than we mean. For instance, if I say ‚ÄòCould you pass me the salt‚Äô, I expect somebody to pass me the salt, and not just say ‚ÄòYes I could‚Äô or ‚ÄòNo, I couldn‚Äôt‚Äô. Why, then, not just say: ‚ÄòPass me the salt‚Äô? In this talk, Professor Hedde Zeijlstra presents the most recent insights on how the meaning of a sentence is derived.

20. Juni 2016: Prof. Dr. Hedde Zeijlstra, English Philology, G√∂ttingen
More information https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/539996.html

title: Functional and Dysfunctional Brain Networks
description:
The brain is modularly organized in areas that preferentially work together forming networks. For mastering our daily challenges, the networks should be able to properly communicate and dynamically interact. But when impairments in this system occur, will we ever be able to reliably identify the problem and fix it? Is decoding the system itself a precondition to achieve this goal? How complex can this decoding be? Can it be used as a master key for all brains or has each brain its own type of key? These questions are used as a starting point to this talk.

6. Juni 2016: Dr. Roberto Goya-Maldonado, University Medical Center G√∂ttingen. 

More information https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/539996.html

title: Religi√∂se Erwecker in der Hohen Kaiserzeit

Die Religion der Kaiserzeit ist gekennzeichnet durch konzentrierte und reduzierte Restriktion, Detraditionalisierung und Verst√§rkung von Individualisierung. Insofern als sie Stabilit√§t von au√üen sucht, ist sie exzentrisch. Ihr gegen√ºber steht der Oberschichtendiskurs der Bildung (Paideia), der eine solche Stabilit√§t gerade durch Traditionsbezug und aktive Selbstformung sucht. Im Spannungsfeld zwischen Religion und Bildung steht die G√∂tterfurcht, Deisidaimon√≠a. Sie ist einerseits Voraussetzung f√ºr religi√∂se Erweckung, andererseits l√§uft sie Gefahr, Scharlatanen aufzusitzen. Gebildete nutzen Deisidaimonie einerseits als Experimentalfeld peripherer Episteme, andererseits als Demarkationslinie gegen√ºber der naiven Masse. Textausz√ºge aus dem Werk des Lukian von Sam√≥sata verdeutlichen die Komplexit√§t entsprechender Debatten innerhalb des zeitgen√∂ssischen Bildungsdiskurses und die daraus resultierende einerseits aggressive, andererseits verunsicherte Haltung gegen√ºber religi√∂sen Erweckern.

title: Religi√∂se Bildung im Alten Testament und in Qumran
description:
Der G√∂ttinger Alttestamentler Prof. Dr. Reinhard G. Kratz, Leiter eines Teilprojekts im Sonderforschungsbereich 1136 ‚ÄûBildung und Religion", spricht √ºber ‚ÄûReligi√∂se Bildung im Alten Testament und in Qumran‚Äú im Gedenken an die Novemberpogrome des Jahres 1938. Der Vortrag besch√§ftigt sich mit der Frage, welche Rolle Bildung, insbesondere religi√∂se Erziehung und Bildung, in der Auseinandersetzung des Judentums mit fremden Kulturen und in der Verfolgung und Vernichtung des Judentums durch andere Kulturen gespielt hat. Sowohl in der Antike wie in der Moderne gab es verschiedene Str√∂mungen im Judentum: eine, die sich anpasste und den Anschluss an die fremde Kultur, in der man lebt, suchte, und eine andere, die sich davon distanzierte und die Grenzen gegen√ºber anderen markierte. Das Alte Testament und die Gemeinschaft von Qumran geh√∂ren der zweiten Gruppe an. Beide Richtungen sind der gelehrten Polemik, dem Hass und der Verfolgung durch fremde Kulturen zum Opfer gefallen. Der Vortrag stellt die verschiedenen Richtungen des antiken Judentums und ihre Konzepte der religi√∂sen Bildung vor und konfrontiert sie mit den Entwicklungen im 19. und 20. Jahrhundert, die zur Zerst√∂rung der zentralen Bildungseinrichtungen des Judentums, den Synagogen, und schlie√ülich in die Shoa f√ºhrten.
